svcproc.title: OPERATION
svcproc.para: There are many different cranking motor circuits used on various applications. The cranking circuit may contain a key start switch, push button switch, a relay, magnetic switches, solenoids, oil pressure switch and other protective devices.

note.para: Reference should be made to the vehicle wiring diagram for the complete cranking circuit.

svcproc.para: A basic circuit of a 37-MT is shown in Figure 7and a 42-MT/50-MT circuit is shown in Figure 8. A circuit with a thermostat for the 42-MT and 50-MT is shown in Figure 9. The thermostat used with the 50-MT is shown in Figure 10 and that used with the 42-MT in Figure 11. The built-in thermostat protects against damage from excessively long periods of over-cranking.

calloutgroup.callout1: 3. THERMOSTAT (PERMANENTLY ATTACHED INSIDE MOTOR TO FIELD COILS)

svcproc.para: When the start switch is closed, battery current flows through the magnetic switch winding and the thermostat to ground, as shown in Figure 9. The magnetic switch closes, connecting the motor solenoid "S" terminal to the battery.

For all circuits, when the start switch is closed, the magnetic switch contacts close, and the solenoid windings are connected to the battery. The resulting plunger and shift lever movement causes the pinion to engage the engine flywheel ring gear and the solenoid main contacts to close, and cranking takes place. When the engine starts, the pinion clutch protects the armature from excessive overrun speed until the switch is opened, at which time the return spring causes the pinion to disengage.

To prevent excessive overrun and damage to the drive and armature windings, the switch must be opened immediately when the engine starts. A cranking period for all types of motors should never exceed 30 seconds without stopping. After 30 seconds of cranking allow the motor to cool for at least two minutes.

The 30 second limit also applies to motors with a thermostat. If over-cranking should occur, the thermostat will open and the cranking cycle will stop to protect the motor. After the cranking motor cools, usually 1 - 6 minutes, the thermostat will close and then a new starting attempt can be made.
